node.title: Constant anisotropy mobility
node.bodyText:
Hello!
I am working on phase transformation using KKS method. I am trying to implement anisotropic mobility as follows:
  [CHBulk]
    type = KKSSplitCHCRes
    variable = c
    ca = cf
    fa_name = ff
    w = w
  []
  [dcdt1]
    type = CoupledTimeDerivative
    variable = w
    v = 'c cb cf eta'
  []
  [ckernel]
    type = SplitCHWResAniso
    variable = w
    mob_name = M
    coupled_variables = 'cb cf eta'
[]
...
[Materials]
  [mob]
    type = ConstantAnisotropicMobility
    tensor = '0.1 0 0
              0   1 0
              0   0 0'
    M_name = M
  []
[]

But I am getting the following error:
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "mob", of type "ConstantAnisotropicMobility".

The declared non-AD material property 'M' of type 'libMesh::TensorValue<double>'
is already retrieved or declared as a non-AD property of type 'double'.

Can you please help me identifying the issue here?
Thank you
Ashish

Hello
I think you just need to make that material AD.
Try prefixing the type of the material with AD

Hello,
Can you give me some more information on how to do it? is it something related to MaterialADConverter? Can I find some example for reference?
Thank you
Ashish

If I use MaterialADConverter with input and output property name as same 'M' I am getting following error.
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "non_ad_local_damage", of type "MaterialADConverter".

The requested AD material property 'M' of type 'double'
is already retrieved or declared as a non-AD property of type 'double'.

Ashish
The MaterialADconverter is not meant for tensors. So you can't use it here
What should be the correct way to do it?

Try
Type = ADConstantAnisotropicMobility

Still same error,
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "mob", of type "ADConstantAnisotropicMobility".

The declared AD material property 'M' of type 'libMesh::TensorValue<double>'
is already retrieved or declared as a non-AD property of type 'double'.

Ok reading the error message again
You are creating the mobility as a tensor but one of the objects is requesting it as a simple number

does KKS CH bulk is causing it? If I run the example script from the website for SplitCHWResAniso it is running, but if I am using same kernels in my script it is not working. is there any other way to define the anisotrpy in kks models?
That's likely. You should check the code that kernel to see the type of the material property used in that kernel for mobility
I think the material property that is asked by SplitCHWResAniso is tensor (const MaterialProperty & _mob;) yet it still is not accepting the tensor value supplied in the input file.
What error are you getting now?

Hi,
Surprisingly it is working now. I made no changes at all. It is strange to me what might have happened before but there is no error now. Although I am not getting the results as expected, but, I think it has something to do with the way I made my input file. So at the moment there is no error.
Thank you Guillaume.
Ashish

node.title: Steady-state simulation using THM
node.bodyText:
Hello, I encountered a problem at run time with "Vector tag 'TIME' does not exist. This may occur if you have a TimeKernel in your problem but did not specify a transient executioner". When I simulated a single flow channel without junctions, THM using the Steady executioner worked without error. But for a singlel flow channel with junctions, THM using the Steady executioner failed to run.
Is it unsupported to run THM with the Steady executioner for a model including junctions? Do I have to simulate this steady-state problem using the Transient executioner by setting steady_state_dection=true?

Hello
A junction you are using must have a time kernel.
Either:
Find which junction that is and add code to prevent adding the time kernel in a steady solve
Use a transient executioner and let it run to steady state. It's the same as a steady solve in terms of results
@joshuahansel there might be a thing to change in a junction here

Thank you very much for your rapid reply! I think the first choice you given is better than the second. Using a transient executioner and let it run to steady state can get identical results, but the computing time will be longer than the Steady executioner?

@joshuahansel there might be a thing to change in a junction here

I am using JunctionParallelChannels1Phase, from which ODETimeDerivative is added by addMooseObjects as shown in its source file. From my point, a small change to this routine is gonna solve my problem, is it right?
I think so

I made a small change to addMooseObjects,  just let it omit the addition of ODETimeDerivative. For a single flow channel with junctions by using the Steady executioner, the mentioned problem was solved. But I encountered a new problem. THM got an error with the following:
0 Nonlinear |R| = 2.295593e+02
Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_PC_FAILED iterations 0
PC failed due to FACTOR_NUMERIC_ZEROPIVOT
Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_FNORM_NAN iterations 0
Solve Did NOT Converge!
Aborting as solve did not converge
I don't know what problem it is. Could you please give me some advice?

Can you try adding -pc_factor_shift NONZERO to your petsc options?
There is a troubleshooting page on our website for convergence issues
Also, maybe it could be your initial guess? I know I've tried Steady simulations with THM before and diverged with a bad initial guess, like the velocity being zero.

This unconverged problem was solved by using improved petsc options, which are recommended by the Porous_Flow module. Here is the url: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/porous_flow/solvers.html. Thank you two very much!

node.title: error : A 'DarcyPressure' is not a registered object.
node.bodyText:
*** ERROR ***
A 'DarcyPressure' is not a registered object.

If you are trying to find this object in a dynamically loaded library, make sure that
the library can be found either in your "Problem/library_path" parameter or in the
MOOSE_LIBRARY_PATH environment variable.

I tried to create objects as problem and kernel, but always got this "not a registered object". So I copied DarcyPressure example in the tutorial, still got the same error. I created the head file(.h) and source file(.cpp) for DarcyPressure, and only changed the lineregisterMooseObject("capybaraApp", DarcyPressure); where capybara is my app name. I am using a mac system and I did make process before running inputfile.  I put the head file in include folder, and put source file in folder under src/kernels/.
Could you please help me with this?

Hello
How is capybaraapp spelled in the base/ ... app.C file?
Any mismatch, caps included, between the registering and the name of the app will get you this error
Guillaume

ok so the name of the app is correct.
Where did you place this object source file? in your_app/src/kernels?
did you re-compile since you added the object? Did the compilation complete with no error message?

Hey
GiudGiud
I ran into the same problem, writing my own header and source files for material types and placing them within include and Src in my app.here is the headfile:

and my C.file also has  registerMooseObject("recrystallizationApp", NucleationProbability);

And the compilation complete with no error message,but  the same problem occurs
Can you register this object to MooseApp for now?

Still can't，
Is there a problem with the file format

Your file must not be getting compiled. Are you sure you are using a newly compiled executable? And that the file is inside that app s folder?
Alternatively
git commit the file
Then git clean -xfd the repository and rebuild after

It was in the folder：

i donot know how to git commit the file
I was just reinstalling moose，So I don't think the above command is going to work

git add src
Git add include
Git commit

node.title: Spatial Derivative
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hello,
I am attempting to implement a kernel in MOOSE that contains the directional derivative (d/dx) of a material property. Is there a way to take the gradient or directional derivative of a material property inside the kernel and/or the materials system? If not, what is the best way to implement this?
It seems like this would be straightforward to do in an AuxKernel, but the material property is dependent on the gradient of the kernel variable (_grad_u) and should be compatible with automatic differentiation (AD) to be computed inside the kernel.
Another solution would be to use adCoupledGradient() to retrieve the gradient of this material property, and while I am new to MOOSE, from my understanding this applies only to coupled variables and not to material properties.
Thank you! Let me know if you need any more information or clarification.

Hello
No the easiest and cleanest way to do this is to define the spatial derivative (gradient) of the material property in either the same Material object or in a new one.
The other clean way of doing this is reworking the material to use the derivativeMaterialInterface to compute these derivatives automatically
Thank you! That reinforces the suggestions you made in Discussion #20628, and that is very helpful.

node.title: Momentum inlet type and function sized wont match.
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A Navier Stokes is the most appropriate category for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (avoid screenshots if possible, triple back quotes before/after pasted text, etc)

Question
I am working on using the Navier-stokesFV action module for wave movement using a variable velocity. However I am unable to get the momentum_inlet_type and momentum_inlet_funtion to match sizes. my exact error is
"(Modules/NavierStokesFV/momentum_inlet_function):  Size (1) is not the same as the number of fixed-velocity and fixed-pressure entries in momentum_inlet_types (size 0)" I have set the type to be flux-velocity however it still says im using fixed velocity and pressure is the error?
'''
[Modules]
[NavierStokesFV]
# General params
compressibility = 'incompressible'
add_energy_equation = true
# Material properties
density = 'rho'
dynamic_viscosity = 'mu'
thermal_conductivity = 'k'
specific_heat = 'cp'

# Initial conditinons
initial_velocity = '1 1 0'
initial_pressure = 1.0
initial_temperature = 0.0

# "inlet" boundary conditions
inlet_boundaries = '3'
momentum_inlet_types = 'flux-velocity'
momentum_inlet_function = '1 ((2.9683*10^3)*sin(t*((2*pi)/(1.2*10^-8))))' #'pressure_z'
energy_inlet_types = 'fixed-temperature'
energy_inlet_function = '0'

#"wall" boundary conditions
wall_boundaries = 'rmax'
momentum_wall_types = 'noslip '
energy_wall_types = 'fixed-temperature'
#energy_wall_function = '0 0 1'

#"outlet" boundary conditions
pin_pressure = true
pinned_pressure_type = average
pinned_pressure_value = 0

#dont have but could include temp params


mass_advection_interpolation = 'average'
momentum_advection_interpolation = 'average'
energy_advection_interpolation = 'average'

[]
[]
'''
Additional information
Mesh size and type:
Reynolds number:
Discretization (finite element CG/DG, finite volume, etc):
Models (turbulence, porous media, etc):
Solver method (fully coupled, segregated, multiapps, etc):
Base input you started from:

Hello
The flux-velocity inlet type is not a fixed velocity BC. You specify it with another parameter giving the fluxes instead
Are you trying to specify a fixed (varying in time) velocity? If so change the inlet type
Guillaume

Hi!
Thank you for your reply, I am trying to make a fixed velocity that is dependent on time. I assumed that a fixed velocity had to be non-changing.
thank you
Ben

node.title: Totally different variable value when using FXs
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I'm learning to use FXs, and here's the model, a cylinder with 8 slots on the edge, with each surface of the slots applied a Dirichlet BCs, all the other surfaces applied 0-flux Neumann BCs.
I Use FXVolumeUserObject to get a functional expansion of temperature distribution (Use AuxVariable T_FXS to get UserObject result), input file be like
main.txt
The calculation converge well, but the expansional T_FXs differs greatly with solved T, shown as below:

What could be the reason for this?

Hello
First you should try with a cylindrical mesh. Once it works there you can move on to this more interesting shape.
Functoonal expansion suffer a lot from being used on a geometry that does not match what they were derived for. I have seen some large deviations from simply using a first order coarse cylinder
Guillaume

Hello Guillaume,
I try with a simple cylinder just now, the functional expansion result is well consistent with calculated one. I didn't change any FXs-related input.
While I'm still not sure what that says with my problem. Do you have any further suggestions?
Thanks for your reply!

My guess at this point is that when you use a non cylindrical shape to perform the integral, you get the completely wrong answer because you are effectively integrating a 0 value in the parts of the cylinder that do not overlap with the geometry.
Another side effect that may be relevant is that the polynomials are not orthogonal on this new domain. So the projection is not as straightforward anymore
From there:

either derive a new polynomial family adapted to your geometry
create a bijective mapping from your geometry to a cylinder and modify the code to use it for the projection and the reconstruction
or make corrections to the current one to account for non orthogonality

You will want to work on a simple geometry to do this again. Either an ellipse or a square. Once it works there, you can move on to your complex shape
Thanks for the suggestion, I may need some time to try.

node.title: Definition of destructor of materials class

node.bodyText:
Hello
You can call this API in the destructor of your new class. You ll want to make sure the default class destructor is mostly still called though.
You can do that by calling the base class destructor in your class destructor
Guillaume

Hi, I tried the following definition for the destructor.
GmTernary::~GmTernary()
  {
	if(_m_pfm_sdk != NULL){
		cout<<"Deleting PFM_SDK pointer ..."<<endl;
		Delete_PFM_SDK( _m_pfm_sdk );
	}
	~DerivativeMaterialInterface<Material>();
  }
But I get the following compilation error
Checking if header needs updating: /home/kamalnath/projects/moose/framework/include/base/MooseRevision.h...
Creating Unity /home/kamalnath/projects/panmoose/build/unity_src/materials_Unity.C
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/kamalnath/projects/panmoose/build/unity_src/materials_Unity.C...
   32 | #warning \
      |  ^~~~~~~
In file included from /home/kamalnath/projects/panmoose/build/unity_src/materials_Unity.C:2:
/home/kamalnath/projects/panmoose/src/materials/GmTernary.C: In destructor ‘virtual GmTernary::~GmTernary()’:
/home/kamalnath/projects/panmoose/src/materials/GmTernary.C:30:41: error: no matching function for call to ‘DerivativeMaterialInterface<Material>::DerivativeMaterialInterface()’
   30 |  ~DerivativeMaterialInterface<Material>();
      |                                         ^
In file included from /home/kamalnath/projects/panmoose/build/header_symlinks/GmTernary.h:5,
                 from /home/kamalnath/projects/panmoose/src/materials/GmTernary.C:1,
                 from /home/kamalnath/projects/panmoose/build/unity_src/materials_Unity.C:2:
/home/kamalnath/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/DerivativeMaterialInterface.h:198:1: note: candidate: ‘DerivativeMaterialInterface<T>::DerivativeMaterialInterface(const InputParameters&) [with T = Material]’
  198 | DerivativeMaterialInterface<T>::DerivativeMaterialInterface(const InputParameters & parameters)
      | ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
/home/kamalnath/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/DerivativeMaterialInterface.h:198:1: note:   candidate expects 1 argument, 0 provided
/home/kamalnath/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/DerivativeMaterialInterface.h:32:7: note: candidate: ‘DerivativeMaterialInterface<Material>::DerivativeMaterialInterface(const DerivativeMaterialInterface<Material>&)’
   32 | class DerivativeMaterialInterface : public T, public DerivativeMaterialPropertyNameInterface
      |       ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
/home/kamalnath/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/DerivativeMaterialInterface.h:32:7: note:   candidate expects 1 argument, 0 provided
/home/kamalnath/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/DerivativeMaterialInterface.h:32:7: note: candidate: ‘DerivativeMaterialInterface<Material>::DerivativeMaterialInterface(DerivativeMaterialInterface<Material>&&)’
/home/kamalnath/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/DerivativeMaterialInterface.h:32:7: note:   candidate expects 1 argument, 0 provided
make: *** [/home/kamalnath/projects/moose/framework/build.mk:149: /home/kamalnath/projects/panmoose/build/unity_src/materials_Unity.x86_64-pc-linux-gnu.opt.lo] Error 1

nevermind you dont need to call the parent class destructor, that's done automatically
https://isocpp.org/wiki/faq/dtors#cant-overload-dtors
@KamalnathOSU please let us know if we can mark this as answered

node.title: How can I get or calculate the gradient of the surface normal？
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A Navier Stokes is the most appropriate category for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (avoid screenshots if possible, triple back quotes before/after pasted text, etc)

Question
Hi there,
Does anyone know how to calculate the gradient of the surface normal? In my application, I consider the surface tension force and it need to calculate the surface curvature. According the equation it is equal to the gradient of the surface normal.
However, I browsed the framework source file only found the _normals and _ad_normals.
Additional information
No response
@lindsayad did you have a surface tension term in the melt pool?

Yes, but it's only computed through a correlation with the temperature. @Always-kimi we do compute curvatures in libMesh and in MOOSE assembly. You can retrieve curvatures with automatic differentiation (AD) information, via _assembly.adCurvatures(). We do also have an Assembly member for curvatures without AD, but we strangely don't have an API for it. It could be easily added
Thank you very much! I found it.
